title: While you were sleeping, Tiger Woods stormed to a first-round lead in Japan
text:
American golf fans probably will rue sleeping through what came next, however. Woods followed that 3-over-par start with birdies on four of the next six holes to close his first nine and then five more birdies with no bogeys on the last nine. When he was finished, he had carded a 6-under 64 for a share of the lead with defending U.S. Open champion Gary Woodland. It was his lowest PGA Tour round since he shot a 62 to open the 2018 BMW Championship, and the lowest season-opening round of his career.

“It’s always nice to get off to a quick start and figure it out from there,” Woods said, per the Associated Press. “The start I got off to wasn’t very good, I hit bad shot after bad shot … and the next thing you know, things aren’t looking so good.”

AD

AD

Woods’s nine birdies were one shy of his personal-best for a PGA Tour round and the most he’s made in one round since a victory at Doral in 2013. His 64 was the lowest round of his career when hitting three or fewer fairways and tied for the lowest round of his career when carding at least three bogeys. The 7.23 strokes he gained over the field was his best mark since the 2012 Arnold Palmer invitational.

With three more similar rounds, he very well could tie all-time leader Sam Snead with his 82nd career PGA Tour win.

Remains to be seen if he'll hold the 1st round lead outright, but Tiger is 10-for-16 (62.5%) in his PGA Tour career with the outright 18-hole lead.



Insane Tiger stat no. 54,381:



In comparison, Jack Nicklaus' win percentage on the PGA Tour with a 54-hole lead/co-lead was 59.3% — Justin Ray (@JustinRayGolf) October 24, 2019

“After the start, the ball striking was better, the putting was really good,” Woods said. “I was hitting a lot of good putts, the ball was rolling tight which was nice."

AD

The Zozo Championship at Accordia Golf Narashino Country Club in Inzai City, Japan, is Woods’s first PGA Tour tournament since he had arthroscopic knee surgery in August. After his stirring Masters victory in April, Woods played in only six more tournaments all season, missing the cut at both the PGA Championship and British Open and failing to qualify for the season-ending FedEx Cup tournament finale. Earlier this week, Woods pointed to his knee as the reason his season went downhill.

AD

“It’s been nice to be able to squat down and read putts and start going at it full speed again,” Woods said after Monday’s skins game in Japan. “It’s just been wear-and-tear over the years. It’s just been stressed out for a very long time.”

Conditions were windy Thursday and seem likely to only get worse, with predicted heavy rain causing Friday’s tee times to be moved up.

AD

“It’s going to be a grind,'' Woods said, per ESPN. “There’s probably going to be a lot of golf on the weekend for all of us.”

Read more from The Post:

AD
description: After three bogeys to start, Woods has one of the lowest rounds of his career.
